review.title: Bacterial Foraging Optimized STATCOM for Stability Assessment in Power System
review.abstract: This paper presents a study of improvement in stability in a single machine connected to infinite bus (SMIB) power system by using static compensator (STATCOM). The gains of Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller in STATCOM are being optimized by heuristic technique based on Particle swarm optimization (PSO). Further, Bacterial Foraging Optimization (BFO) as an alternative heuristic method is also applied to select optimal gains of PID controller. The performance of STATCOM with the above soft-computing techniques are studied and compared with the conventional PID controller under various scenarios. The simulation results are accompanied with performance indices based quantitative analysis. The analysis clearly signifies the robustness of the new scheme in terms of stability and voltage regulation when compared with conventional PID.

Therefore, it is necessary to control reactive power to reduce the difference between power generation and load demand. In order to improve the quality, stability and reliability of the power supply, it can also lead to transient stability oscillations.

sections.heading: D. PSO-PID Controller
sections.text: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is one of the heuristic algorithms proposed by Kennedy and Eberhaut in 1995, based on the behavior of the swarm in search of food in a multidimensional space, based on their own experience and that of the group members, such as in fish farming, bird flocking practice, etc. [14] - [15] PSO, due to its high efficiency, is fast and simplest structure, very popular in recent years for tuning PID controllers. sections.text: In this process of foraging, each bacterium remains in search of food with the avoidance of harmful substances and always tries to make the most of it. In this process of foraging, the bacterium communicates with each other by sending signals. sections.heading: A. Stability test under normal loading
sections.text: To verify the performance of the proposed stabilizers under normal load conditions, the following variations caused by a fault are taken into account: (a) nominal load (P, Q, V) = (0.7, 0.3, 1.0) pu; it is observed that when simulating the SMIB system with STATCOM controller with PID controller, PSO-PID and BFOPID, the fluctuation of the system voltage provides oscillation control around the nominal voltage of 1 pu, as shown in Figure 5 (a). The corresponding variation in the system angle frequency is shown in Figure 5 (b).

sections.heading: B. Stability test under smaller variation in loading
sections.text: Once again, the stability of STATCOM is tested in the SMIB under lower load fluctuations (10-20% over nominal value) and the deviations considered are described below using error-related parameters: (b) nominal load (P, Q, V) = (1.2, 0.4, 1.15) pu; STATCOM is observed with PID controller, PSO-PID and BFO-PID controller, which stabilizes the voltage of the SMIB remotely, as shown in Figure 6 (a), where the nominal voltage is 1 pu. Also, the deviation of the angular frequency under the same operating state is shown in Figure 6 (b). Again, it is observed that both PSO and BFO stabilize the voltage and frequency relatively better than the conventional PID controller, which is designed for heuristic hit-and-trial tuning method, thus reducing times.
